caption: A photograph showing “kill markings” that indicate flying saucers on the side of a German World War II anti-aircraft gun

result.explanation: The image clearly shows a German World War II anti-aircraft gun.  The caption mentions "kill markings" indicating flying saucers, which are not visible in the provided image. Therefore, while the entities related to the gun are correctly identified and present, the claim about the "kill markings" is not supported by the image.

candidates.title: Is Photo of WWII-Era German Tank That Shot Down UFOs Real?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A photograph shows UFO "kill markings" on the side of a German World War II anti-aircraft gun.
Rating:
False
About this rating
A photograph purportedly showing "kill markings" that indicate flying saucers on the side of a German World War II anti-aircraft gun has been showing up on the internet for several years, often used as proof that unidentified flying objects are a part of the historical record because a "German tank shot down a UFO":
This digitally manipulated image has been circulating since at least 2013 when it was published in the "Humor" section of the Mod DB web forum under the title "I never though the Flak 88 were THAT versatile."
While the photograph does show a German Flak 88mm anti-aircraft gun, the UFO markings were not part of the original photograph:
The original photograph was lifted from the cover of a 1943 issue of Der Adler, a Nazi propaganda magazine:
The caption identified the kill markings on the weapon as 11 planes, 40 armored tanks, and 15 anti-aircraft forts. There was no mention of UFOs.
candidates.description: A photograph purportedly showing kill markings that indicate flying saucers on a WWII-era anti-aircraft gun has been digitally manipulated.

result.explanation: The provided evidence directly contradicts the news caption. Source 1 explicitly states that the photograph showing "kill markings" indicating flying saucers on a German WWII anti-aircraft gun is digitally manipulated.  The original image, from a Nazi propaganda magazine, shows kill markings for conventional targets (planes, tanks, anti-aircraft forts), with no mention of UFOs.  Therefore, the news caption's claim is false.
result.supporting_points: Source 1: The photograph purportedly showing "kill markings" that indicate flying saucers on a WWII-era anti-aircraft gun has been digitally manipulated.  The original photograph was lifted from the cover of a 1943 issue of Der Adler, a Nazi propaganda magazine: The caption identified the kill markings on the weapon as 11 planes, 40 armored tanks, and 15 anti-aircraft forts. There was no mention of UFOs.

final_result.explanation: The internal and external validation processes both strongly indicate that the original news caption is out of context. The internal check reveals a discrepancy between the caption's claim of "kill markings" indicating flying saucers and the actual image content, which shows only a German World War II anti-aircraft gun without any such markings. The external check corroborates this by citing a source that confirms the claim about flying saucers is false and that the image has been digitally manipulated.  The original image, from a Nazi propaganda magazine, displays kill markings for conventional targets (planes, tanks, anti-aircraft forts).  The high confidence scores (10/10 for both checks) reinforce the conclusion that the caption is factually incorrect and significantly misrepresents the image. There is complete agreement between the internal and external checks, confirming the caption's inaccuracy and lack of context.  The image itself does not show any evidence of flying saucer kill markings.  Instead, it depicts a German anti-aircraft gun, consistent with the information from the external source that points to the image being a manipulated version of a wartime propaganda photograph. The validation process was thorough and supported by strong evidence.   The complete lack of visual evidence of flying saucer markings and the external source detailing the image's manipulation confirm the caption's out-of-context nature beyond reasonable doubt.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation processes strongly support the conclusion that the news caption is out of context.  The image lacks the described "kill markings," and external sources confirm the caption's claim to be false and the image digitally manipulated.
